verses.text: Then Solomon began to build the house of the LORD in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah, where the LORD had appeared to David his father, on the place that David had prepared on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
verses.comment: Mount Moriah is a significant location, as it links back to Abraham's offering of Isaac (Genesis 22:2), prefiguring the sacrificial offering fulfilled in Christ. The specific selection and preparation of the site shows a divine plan, and a continuity of tradition and leadership from David to Solomon.

verses.text: He began to build on the second day of the second month, in the fourth year of his reign.
verses.comment: The precise dating reflects the importance of sacred chronology in biblical narrative and emphasizes the orderly fulfillment of God's promises through Israel's kings.

verses.text: Now these are the foundations which Solomon laid for building the house of God: the length, in cubits by the former measure, was sixty cubits, and the width twenty cubits.
verses.comment: The mention of the 'former measure' preserves the connection to ancient tradition. The house of God’s proportions prefigure the heavenly order and the Church as the temple of the Holy Spirit (cf. Eph. 2:21).

verses.text: The vestibule in front of the house was twenty cubits long, equal to the width of the house, and its height was one hundred and twenty cubits. He overlaid it inside with pure gold.
verses.comment: The extraordinary height of the vestibule (unique to Chronicles) reveals the majesty of God and the glory of His dwelling place among His people. Gold symbolizes divine glory and purity.

verses.text: He paneled the main hall with cypress wood, overlaid it with fine gold, and carved palm trees and chain patterns on it.
verses.comment: The use of cypress and gold, and the intricate carvings, echoes the beauty and holiness required in worship. The artistic symbols point to the new creation and the fruitful life of the faithful.

verses.text: He adorned the house with precious stones for beauty, and the gold used was gold from Parvaim.
verses.comment: The decoration with precious stones reflects the heavenly Jerusalem (cf. Rev. 21:19), anticipating the Church as the radiant bride of Christ, adorned for her Lord.

verses.text: He overlaid the house, the beams, the thresholds, its walls and its doors with gold, and carved cherubim on the walls.
verses.comment: Cherubim represent the presence of God and His angels. Gold covering the central parts of the temple symbolizes completeness in worship, echoing heavenly liturgy (cf. Heb. 8:5).

verses.text: He made the Most Holy Place, its length equal to the width of the house, twenty cubits, and its width twenty cubits. He overlaid it with six hundred talents of fine gold.
verses.comment: The Most Holy Place foreshadows the inner sanctum of God's presence with His people. In Christ, the veil between God and man is removed (cf. Heb. 10:19-22), opening the way into the true sanctuary.

verses.text: The weight of the nails was fifty shekels of gold. He also overlaid the upper rooms with gold.
verses.comment: The detailed mention of the gold for even nails and upper chambers highlights the total dedication of the whole structure to God. In the spiritual sense, the Church is built up in all its parts with the richness of divine grace.

verses.text: In the Most Holy Place he made two cherubim of sculptured work, and overlaid them with gold.
verses.comment: The cherubim, guardians of God's sanctuary, again show a link between God’s presence and heavenly worship. These images are not idols but point towards the reality of angels in worship and the importance of visible beauty in sanctuaries (cf. Rev. 5:11).

verses.text: The wings of the cherubim had a total length of twenty cubits: one wing of the first cherub was five cubits, touching the wall of the house; its other wing was also five cubits, touching the wing of the other cherub.
verses.comment: The spanning wings suggest God's protective covering over His people. The symmetry and contact evoke unity and order in the presence of God.

verses.text: The wing of the other cherub was five cubits, touching the wall of the house; and its other wing, also five cubits, was touching the wing of the first cherub.
verses.comment: Both cherubim are described in detail, emphasizing symmetry and perfection in God’s dwelling. The overlap reinforces the unity and wholeness of divine protection.

verses.text: The wings of these cherubim spread out to twenty cubits in total. They stood on their feet, and their faces were turned toward the main hall.
verses.comment: Their orientation toward the main hall (the nave) suggests openness to the worshipers and a conduit of blessing from God, prefiguring access to God through Christ (cf. John 10:9).

verses.text: He made the veil of blue, purple, crimson, and fine linen, and worked cherubim into it.
verses.comment: The veil with cherubim recalls the tabernacle, separating the Most Holy from the Holy Place. In Christ’s sacrifice, this veil is torn (Matthew 27:51), signifying our new access to God through Him. The colors and materials indicate a heavenly beauty in worship.

verses.text: In front of the house he made two pillars, thirty-five cubits high, and the capital that was on the top of each was five cubits.
verses.comment: These pillars, later named Jachin and Boaz, symbolize stability and strength. They stand at the entrance, signifying the establishment of God’s promise and the faith needed to enter His presence.

verses.text: He made chains as in the inner sanctuary, and placed them on the tops of the pillars; and he made one hundred pomegranates, and put them on the chains.
verses.comment: Pomegranates symbolize abundance and life, reflecting the fruitful grace at the entrance to God’s house. Chains connect and protect, indicating unity and continuity in worship and faith.

verses.text: He set up the pillars in front of the temple, one on the right and the other on the left. He named the one on the right Jachin, and the one on the left Boaz.
verses.comment: ‘Jachin’ means 'He establishes' and ‘Boaz’ means 'In Him is strength.’ The names signify God's faithfulness in establishing His people firmly in His promises, a theme carried on through Christ and the enduring foundation of His Church. See also Matt. 16:18.
